#1 git config.content: This command defines the name of the author that will appear in the commits.
This command defines the author's email that will appear in the commits.

#2 git init.content: This command is used to start a new repository.

#3 git clone.content: This command is used to obtain a repository from an existing URL.

#4 git status.content: This command lists all the files that have to be committed.

#5 git add.content: This command adds a file to the staging area.
This command adds one or more to the staging area.

#6 git commit.content: This command records or snapshots the file permanently in the version history.

#7 git diff.content: This command shows the file differences which are not yet staged.
This command shows the differences between the files in the staging area and the latest version present.
This command shows the differences between the two branches mentioned.

#8 git restore.content: This command restores the contents of the file to that of the last commit.

#9 git reset.content: This command unstages the file, but it preserves the file contents.
This command undoes the last commit and moves changes locally to staged.
This command discards the last commit and its contents.

#10 git rm.content: This command deletes the file from your working directory and stages the deletion.

#11 git log.content: This command is used to list the version history for the current branch.
This command lists the commit history of the current branch in just one line.
This command is used to list the commit history of the current branch formatted in one line.
This command displays the log with the changed files and a summary of the change.

#12 git show.content: This command shows the metadata and content changes of the specified commit.
This command displays the modified files in the current commit.
This command displays the modified files in the specific commit.

#13 git tag.content: This command is used to create tag.
This command is used to list existing tags.

#14 git branch.content: This command lists all the local branches in the current repository.
This command creates a new branch.
This command deletes the feature branch.
this command displays the remote branches
this command displays all branches, local and remote

#15 git checkout.content: This command is used to switch from one branch to another.
This command creates a new branch and also switches to it.
This command returns to the previous commit state.
This command goes to the commit state of the tag.
This command advances to the next commit state.
#15 git checkout.code: git checkout $(git rev-list --topo-order HEAD..&ltcurrent branch&gt | tail -1)

#16 git merge.content: This command merges the specified branch's history into the current branch.

#17 git remote.content: This command is used to connect your local repository to the remote server.

#18 git push.content: This command sends the branch commits to your remote repository.
This command sends the committed changes to your remote repository.
This command deletes a branch on your remote repository.
This command pushes tag to your remote repository.
This command deletes a commit already pushed to the remote repository.

#19 git pull.content: This command fetches and merges changes on the remote server to your working directory.

#20 git stash.content: This command temporarily stores all the modified tracked files.
This command restores the most recently stashed files.
This command lists all stashed changesets.
This command discards the most recently stashed changeset.
